claim: Boost.JSON implements JSON as standardized in RFC 8259
dataset_or_code: documentation refers to RFC 8259 for standard format
retrieved_date: Library ensures any value serialized can be deserialized back equal to original, per docs referencing RFC 8259

claim: By default the parser only accepts strictly conforming JSON (UTF-8)
retrieved_date: Default parser accepts only RFC-compliant UTF-8 JSON unless parse_options relaxations used

claim: The parser behavior can be relaxed to allow non-standard syntax like comments or trailing commas
retrieved_date: Non-standard syntax allowed only when parse_options flags are explicitly set

claim: Boost.JSON implements JSON per the definition and spec of RFC 8259
retrieved_date: Overview states library implements JSON standardized in RFC 8259

claim: Glaze requires C++23; uses concepts and standard-compliant code
retrieved_date: Docs state Glaze requires C++23 and uses concepts for cleaner code

claim: Glaze tested on GCC, Clang, MSVC across Linux, macOS, Windows
retrieved_date: Docs list support on multiple compilers and OS

claim: Glaze serializes/deserializes directly from C++ memory with in-memory JSON
retrieved_date: Describes direct memory reads/writes simplifying interface

claim: By default Glaze errors on unknown extra JSON keys; opt-in flag allows skipping unknown keys
retrieved_date: Extra keys cause error unless opts{.error_on_unknown_keys = false} set; primary_doc=TBD

claim: Supports only UTF-8 (default), per RFC 8259
retrieved_date: Only UTF-8 input is supported, as per default JSON spec

claim: Does not support comments by default (non-standard)
retrieved_date: Comments disallowed unless ignore_comments set true

claim: Does not allow trailing commas by default (non-standard)
retrieved_date: Trailing commas disallowed unless ignore_trailing_commas true

claim: parse() takes ignore_comments and ignore_trailing_commas flags
retrieved_date: Flags are opt-in to relax compliance

claim: Objects treated as unordered per JSON spec; insertion order not preserved
retrieved_date: Insertion order not preserved unless using ordered_json

claim: The simdjson library is fully compliant with the RFC 8259 JSON specification
retrieved_date: Official docs claim full RFC 8259 compliance

claim: simdjson was the first standard-compliant JSON parser to process gigabytes per second on single core
retrieved_date: Paper describes first standard-compliant parser achieving GB/s

claim: simdjson offers full unicode (UTF-8) validation and exact number parsing
retrieved_date: Readme notes full UTF-8 validation and exact number parsing

claim: Feature request to allow NaN/Infinity parsing is labeled non-JSON extension
retrieved_date: Non-standard parsing (NaN/Infinity) currently unsupported unless extension

claim: simdjson limits single JSON documents to 4 GiB and refuses larger
retrieved_date: Enforced document size limit noted in basics; verify_in_2x_docs

claim: Boost.JSON provides an incremental SAX-style parser via basic_parser with event callbacks; supports multi-segment input.
stream_parser parses JSON piecewise from multiple buffers into a value; caller feeds chunks via write and finishes to obtain result.
Streaming parse accepts contiguous buffers; whole document need not be resident; callers feed chunks from streams/files/sockets.
Parser handles UTF-8 sequences split across buffers by buffering incomplete multibyte sequences and validating when complete.
Error offset can be derived by incremental feeding: consumed character count indicates failure position (no direct position API).
serializer supports incremental output via repeated reads while traversing a value (streaming serialization).
Default maximum nesting depth is 32; configurable via parse_options; exceeding returns error.
SAX handler provides on_string_part/on_number_part for tokens spanning buffers; final on_string/number emitted when complete.
Parsers and serializer can be reset and reused across multiple documents to reuse internal storage and reduce allocations.
Chunked incremental parsing enables bounded per-iteration CPU/memory and lower latency under backpressure.
Provides a SAX event-driven parser via json::sax_parse over strings or streams.
No incremental (resume) parsing; truncated JSON cannot be resumed.
notes: Community guidance; no official resume API.

claim: JSON Lines/NDJSON not directly supported; expects single JSON value per input.
No pull/on-demand iterator parser; offers DOM and SAX (push) only.
No incremental streaming serialization; output produced in one shot.
ordered_json preserves insertion order; default object order is lexicographic.
Supports output to std::ostream via operator<< (uses dump()).
DOM parse errors throw exceptions with descriptive messages (e.g., parse_error.101).
In SAX mode, parse errors reported via parse_error callback; sax_parse returns false (no throw).
Flexible inputs: parse from std::istream or iterator ranges of (UTF-8/16/32) bytes.
No incremental/chunked parsing; expects contiguous input; default opts.null_terminated=true (can disable with perf tradeoff).
Author notes streaming file parse is slower than reading whole file first; streaming may reduce RAM for huge files.
No coroutine/async JSON parser; JSON functions are synchronous; async exists at HTTP transport level (Asio).
partial_read supports compile-time partial parsing: reads known fields, skips remainder.
Parse errors return error codes; formatter can display exact line/column with caret to location.
By default errors on unknown keys; option error_on_unknown_keys=false skips them; custom unknown_read/unknown_write handlers available.
In-memory (de)serialization without DOM; writes/reads directly to C++ object memory.
Supports NDJSON/JSON Lines via parse_many (DOM) and iterate_many (On Demand), returning a document_stream for per-document iteration.
On Demand API provides on-the-fly parsing of values without building a full DOM (not SAX/event-based).
Parsers can be reused across inputs to reduce allocations; designed for high-throughput incremental workflows.
Requires input padding of SIMDJSON_PADDING bytes (currently 32) at the end of the buffer for safe SIMD parsing.
Default maximum nesting depth is 1024 levels; deeper documents are rejected.
Fully validates UTF-8; reported validation speeds up to ~13 GB/s on Intel Skylake in project README.
